title: 111_s653
content: The Act is titled the "Star-Spangled Banner Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. During the War of 1812, Francis Scott Key witnessed the British bombardment of Fort McHenry and was inspired to write "The Defence of Fort McHenry" after seeing the American flag still flying proudly. In 1916, President Woodrow Wilson popularly renamed the anthem The Star-Spangled Banner and ordered it to be played at military and naval occasions. In 1931, President Herbert Hoover officially designated it as the National Anthem of the United States. The coin specifications are outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins in commemoration of the bicentennial of the Star-Spangled Banner. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender. All coins minted under this Act for the bicentennial of the Star-Spangled Banner will be considered numismatic items under title 31, United States Code. Design of coins for the bicentennial of the Star-Spangled Banner will be considered numismatic items under title 31, United States Code. Design requirements for the coins minted under the Act include being emblematic of the War of 1812, specifically the Battle for Baltimore. Each coin must have a value designation, the year "2012" inscribed, and include words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant commissions and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated Mint facility during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2012. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act will include a surcharge of $35 per coin for the $5 coin and $10 per coin for the $1 coin. The surcharges received will be paid to the Maryland War of 1812 Bicentennial Commission for supporting bicentennial activities, educational outreach, and preservation activities related to the War of 1812. The Comptroller General of the United States will have the right to audit the Commission's expenditures. The Act imposes a limitation on surcharges for commemorative coin programs to prevent exceeding the annual issuance limit. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide guidance for this limitation.
